sentences.sentence: “No thanks,” said Digory, “I don’t know that I care much about living on and on after everyone I know is dead.
I’d rather live an ordinary time and die and go to Heaven.”
“But what about this Mother of yours whom you pretend to love so?”
“What’s she got to do with it?” said Digory.
“Do you not see, Fool, that one bite of that apple would heal( 治愈 ) her?
You have it in your pocket. We are here by ourselves and the Lion is far away.
Use your Magic and go back to your own world.
A minute later you can be at your Mother’s bedside, giving her the fruit.
Five minutes later you will see the color coming back to her face.
She will tell you the pain is gone. Soon she will tell you she feels stronger.
Then she will fall asleep—think of that; hours of sweet natural sleep, without pain, without drugs.
Next day everyone will be saying how wonderfully she has recovered.
Soon she will be quite well again.
All will be well again.
Your home will be happy again.
You will be like other boys.”
“Oh!” gasped( 喘着气说 ) Digory as if he had been hurt, and put his hand to his head.
For he now knew that the most terrible choice lay before him.
“What has the Lion ever done for you that you should be his slave?” said the Witch( 女巫 ).
“What can he do to you once you are back in your own world?
And what would your Mother think if she knew that you could have taken her pain away and given her back her life and saved your Father’s heart from being broken,
and that you wouldn’t—that you’d rather run messages for a wild animal in a strange world that is no business of yours?”
“I—I don’t think he is a wild animal,” said Digory in a dried-up sort of voice. “He is—I don’t know—”
“Then he is something worse,” said the Witch( 女巫 ). “Look what he has done to you already; look how heartless he has made you.
That is what he does to everyone who listens to him. Cruel, pitiless boy! you would let your own Mother die rather than—”
“Oh shut up,” said the miserable( 痛苦的 ) Digory, still in the same voice. “Do you think I don’t see? But I—I promised.”
“Ah, but you didn’t know what you were promising. And no one here can prevent you.”

“Mother herself,” said Digory, getting the words out with difficulty, “wouldn’t like it—awfully strict about keeping promises—and not stealing—and all that sort of thing. She’d tell me not to do it—quick as anything—if she was here.”
“But she need never know,” said the Witch( 女巫 ), speaking more sweetly than you would have thought anyone with so fierce a face could speak.
“You wouldn’t tell her how you’d got the apple.
Your Father need never know.
No one in your world need know anything about this whole story.
You needn’t take the little girl back with you, you know.”
That was where the Witch( 女巫 ) made her fatal( 致命的 ) mistake.
Of course Digory knew that Polly could get away by her own ring as easily as he could get away by his.
But apparently( 明显地 ) the Witch( 女巫 ) didn’t know this.
And the meanness of the suggestion that he should leave Polly behind suddenly made all the other things the Witch( 女巫 ) had been saying to him sound false and hollow( 虚伪的 ).
And even in the midst( 在...之中 ) of all his misery( 痛苦 ), his head suddenly cleared, and he said (in a different and much louder voice):
“Look here; where do you come into all this? Why are you so precious( 极其 ) fond of my Mother all of a sudden? What’s it got to do with you? What’s your game?”
“Good for you, Digs,” whispered Polly in his ear. “Quick! Get away now.” She hadn’t dared to say anything all through the argument because, you see, it wasn’t her Mother who was dying.
“Up then,” said Digory, heaving( 举起 ) her on to Fledge’s back and then scrambling( 爬上 ) up as quickly as he could. The horse spread its wings.
“Go then, Fools,” called the Witch( 女巫 ). “Think of me, Boy, when you lie old and weak and dying, and remember how you threw away the chance of endless youth! It won’t be offered you again.”
They were already so high that they could only just hear her.
Nor did the Witch( 女巫 ) waste any time gazing( 盯着 ) up at them;
they saw her set off northward( 向北 ) down the slope( 斜坡 ) of the hill.
They had started early that morning and what happened in the garden had not taken very long,
so that Fledge and Polly both said they would easily get back to Narnia before nightfall( 夜幕降临 ).
Digory never spoke on the way back, and the others were shy of speaking to him.
He was very sad and he wasn’t even sure all the time that he had done the right thing;
but whenever he remembered the shining tears in Aslan’s eyes he became sure.
All day Fledge flew steadily with untiring( 不知疲倦的 ) wings; eastward( 向东 ) with the river to guide him,
through the mountains and over the wild wooded hills, and then over the great waterfall( 瀑布 ) and down, and down,
to where the woods of Narnia were darkened by the shadow of the mighty cliff( 悬崖 ),
till at last, when the sky was growing red with sunset behind them,
he saw a place where many creatures were gathered together by the riverside.
And soon he could see Aslan himself in the midst( 在中间 ) of them.
Fledge glided( 滑翔 ) down, spread out his four legs, closed his wings, and landed cantering( 小跑 ).
Then he pulled up( 停下 ). The children dismounted( 下马 ).
Digory saw all the animals, dwarfs( 矮人 ), satyrs( （希腊神话中的）森林之神 ), nymphs( 仙女 ), and other things drawing back to the left and right to make way for him.
He walked up to Aslan, handed him the apple and said:
“I’ve brought you the apple you wanted, sir.”
“Well done,” said Aslan in a voice that made the earth shake.
Then Digory knew that all the Narnians had heard those words and that the story of them would be handed down from father to son in that new world for hundreds of years and perhaps forever.
But he was in no danger of feeling conceited( 自以为是的 ) for he didn’t think about it at all now that he was face to face with Aslan.
This time he found he could look straight into the Lion’s eyes.
He had forgotten his troubles and felt absolutely content.
“Well done, son of Adam,” said the Lion again.
“For this fruit you have hungered and thirsted and wept( 流泪 ).
No hand but yours shall sow( 播种 ) the seed of the Tree that is to be the protection of Narnia.
Throw the apple toward the river bank where the ground is soft.”
Digory did as he was told.
Everyone had grown so quiet that you could hear the soft thump( 砰的一声 ) where it fell into the mud( 泥地 ).
“It is well thrown,” said Aslan. “Let us now proceed( 继而做 ) to the coronation( 加冕仪式 ) of King Frank of Narnia and Helen his Queen.”
The children now noticed these two for the first time.
They were dressed in strange and beautiful clothes,
and from their shoulders rich robes( 长袍 ) flowed out behind them to where four dwarfs( 矮人 ) held up the King’s train and four river-nymphs( 河泽仙女 ) the Queen’s.
Their heads were bare( 没有装饰的 ); but Helen had let her hair down and it made a great improvement in her appearance.
But it was neither hair nor clothes that made them look so different from their old selves.
Their faces had a new expression, especially the King’s.
All the sharpness( 尖酸刻薄 ) and cunning( 狡诈 ) and quarrelsomeness( 好争吵 ) which he had picked up( 养成 ) as a London cabby( 马车夫 ) seemed to have been washed away,
and the courage and kindness which he had always had were easier to see.
Perhaps it was the air of the young world that had done it, or talking with Aslan, or both.
“Upon my word,” whispered Fledge to Polly. “My old master’s been changed nearly as much as I have! Why, he’s a real master now.”
“Yes, but don’t buzz( 叽叽喳喳 ) in my ear like that,” said Polly. “It tickles( 使发痒 ) so.”
“Now,” said Aslan, “some of you undo( 松开 ) that tangle( 缠结的一团 ) you have made with those trees and let us see what we shall find there.”

article_info.previous: 到达目的地的一行人站在门口，此时Digory心里明白，现在需要自己一个人来完成使命。当他摘下银苹果准备返回时，邪恶的女巫再次出现在他面前，并且劝诱他不要把苹果带给Aslan，那么Digory会如何抉择呢？

article_info.share_words: Fledge glided down, spread out his four legs, closed his wings, and landed cantering. The he pulled up. The children dismounted.

question.cn: 根据对话内容，Digory想要永生的生命吗？
question.en: According to the conversation, did Digory want to live forever?

analysis: 文中提到： “No thanks,” said Digory, “I don't know that I care much about living on and on after everyone I know is dead. I'd rather live an ordinary time and die and go to Heaven.”由此可知，Digory并不想要永生的生命，因此选B。

question.en: Where did Digory put the silvery apple?

analysis: 文中提到：“You have it in your pocket. We are here by ourselves and the Lion is far away.”通过女巫的话我们得知Digroy把银苹果藏在了他的衣服口袋里，因此选A。

question.cn: 女巫建议Digroy如何处理银苹果？
question.en: What did the Witch advise Digory to do with the silvery apple?

options.en: To give the apple to her.
To give the apple to his mother.
To give the apple to Uncle Andrew.

analysis: 文中提到：“Don’t you see, Fool, that one bite of that apple would heal her. . . a minute later you can be at your Mother’s side, giving her the fruit.”由此可知，女巫在劝诱Digory把苹果给他的妈妈吃，由此可以治好她的病，因此选B。

question.cn: 谁种下了纳尼亚保卫树的种子？
question.en: Who planted the seed of tree that would protect the Narnia?

analysis: 文中提到：“ No hand but yours shall sow the seed of the Tree that is to be the protection of Narnia…Digory did as he was told.”由此可知，Aslan说到，应该由Digory种下他带回来的种子，Digory照做了，因此选B。
